G.L. c. 212, \u00a7\u202f4.proposition: Jurisdiction lies in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the incident occurred within Middlesex County.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain the premises in a safe condition and to protect against foreseeable risks of harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is from a concurrence discussing the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and criticizing the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not articulate or affirm a specific duty owed to a business invitee, nor does it describe the standard of reasonable care to maintain premises for invitees. While the majority opinion in Mounsey is about premises liability duties generally, this particular cited page and concurring text do not support the specific proposition stated.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier is liable for injuries caused by its failure to exercise reasonable care in maintaining its premises.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that Massachusetts premises liability law imposes on property owners a duty to use reasonable care to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, and it applies that same standard to hazards from snow and ice. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction specifically to reaffirm that the governing rule is reasonable care in maintaining the premises, directly aligning with the proposition.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: The standard of care owed to business invitees requires the possessor of land to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the general common-law duty of care owed by an owner or possessor of land to lawful entrants and describes that duty as including an obligation to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. This directly matches the claimed proposition about the standard of care owed to business invitees (lawful visitors) regarding the safety of the premises.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: "An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. Id. at 743. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the 'property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.' Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973)."

*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.proposition: A store is liable where its employees know or should know that merchandise is stacked dangerously high or unsecured.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.support_reasoning: The case concerns liability for a foreign substance on stairs in a subway station, not merchandise stacking or display conditions in a store. Its holding and reasoning address when a possessor of business premises is liable for failing to discover and remove a foreign substance, focusing on the time-on-the-floor requirement, not on knowledge of dangerously stacked or unsecured merchandise. Thus it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition about store liability for dangerously stacked merchandise.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783 (2007).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: A dangerous condition that exists for a sufficient period of time to be discovered and corrected constitutes notice.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion recites the traditional rule that a substance present long enough to be discovered and removed constitutes constructive notice, but the case itself rejects relying on that temporal requirement and instead adopts the "mode of operation" approach, where foreseeability of a recurring risk satisfies notice even without proof of how long the specific condition existed. Thus, Sheehan is authority for a different, more plaintiff-friendly notice standard, not for the proposition that the mere passage of sufficient time constitutes notice. The cited case would be misleading support for that traditional time-based notice proposition.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition. Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955). … Under the mode of operation approach, the plaintiff’s burden to prove notice is not eliminated. Instead, the plaintiff satisfies the notice requirement if he establishes that an injury was attributable to a reasonably foreseeable dangerous condition on the owner’s premises that is related to the owner’s self-service mode of operation.”

*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.proposition: Negligence consists of “failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.”
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence and emphasizes causation, but it does not define negligence as a "failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances." The court cites the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 and a tort treatise for the elements of negligence, but nowhere articulates the reasonably prudent person standard or the quoted language. Thus, the case does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: Causation exists where the negligent conduct was a substantial contributing factor in producing the harm.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses causation in negligence and distinguishes factual causation from proximate (legal) causation. While it uses the term “cause in fact” rather than “substantial factor,” it clearly states that negligent conduct must be causally related to the injury and then be a proximate/legal cause, which aligns with the substantial contributing factor formulation commonly used in Massachusetts negligence law. Thus, it supports the general proposition that negligent conduct must substantially contribute to producing the harm to satisfy causation.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “‘[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff.’ Wainwright v. Jackson, 291 Mass. 100, 102 (1935). See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000) (causation ‘is an essential element’ of proof of negligence). In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935).”

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs.*, 438 Mass.proposition: A business is responsible for the acts and omissions of its employees under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs.*, 438 Mass.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs.*, 438 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses and applies traditional respondeat superior, holding that an employer is vicariously liable for the torts of its employees committed within the scope of employment, without needing to control the specific details of their work. The court explains that, once an employer-employee relationship is established, the employer may be held liable for the employee’s negligent acts occurring within the scope of employment. This squarely supports the general proposition that a business is responsible for acts and omissions of its employees under respondeat superior.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs.*, 438 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer… should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee… committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..proposition: A business is responsible for the acts and omissions of its employees under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent focused entirely on negligence and proximate cause in a premises‑liability context; it does not discuss vicarious liability or respondeat superior at all. Nothing in the reasoning addresses when or whether a business is responsible for the acts or omissions of its employees, so the case as presented does not provide authority for that proposition. If Mullins discusses respondeat superior, it is not in this quoted portion, and this citation to page 62 of the dissent is not supporting that doctrine.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, \u00a.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, § 85 sets forth the applicable comparative negligence standard.

*Kennedy v. Cummings*, 195 Mass. 121 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to follow ordinary safety practices, including safe stacking procedures, constitutes breach of duty under *Kennedy v. Cummings*, 195 Mass. 121 (1907) (duty to prevent foreseeable harm).

*Alecks v. Trustees of Boston Univ.*, 34.raw_text: *Alecks v. Trustees of Boston Univ.*, 341 Mass. 731 (1961).
*Alecks v. Trustees of Boston Univ.*, 34.proposition: Plaintiff thereby suffered physical injury, lost wages, medical expenses, and pain and suffering within the meaning of recoverable tort damages.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u202f6B.proposition: Award costs and interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
